utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Well, here's the thing.

When a candidate tells you about all the things that aren't possible, about how political calculations come first, about how you should settle for little bits and pieces instead of real change, they're telling you something important.
They are telling you they will not fight for you.

A lot of signs that Warren has been getting more momentum lately, and that includes the fact that she drew more than 6,000 people to a rally last night across the bay in Oakland, which, of course, is Kamala Harris's home city.
Indeed.
OK, 14 candidates are there.
Let's do the math.
That leaves nine not there.
Any notable absences?
Absolutely.

Former Vice President Joe Biden, who you could interpret that Warren line about incremental change and keeping the status quo, you could certainly interpret that to be her talking about the way that Biden is approaching this race.
He is not taking the super progressive platform that many other candidates are.
And I think that's part of the reason why he is avoiding this gathering of party activists and officials, who are often even more liberal than most California voters.
In fact, Joe Biden is in Ohio today.
He's basing his appeal on winning back the Midwest, the states that gave Trump the White House.
And there's a lot of symbolism there that Joe Biden is in Ohio instead of California.

But I'll say this, even in this crowd here in San Francisco today, when you talk to voters about what's most important to them, a lot of them are still saying it's all about electability, who can beat Donald Trump.
And that is what Joe Biden is banking voters will see him as.
That's NPR political correspondent Scott Detrow in San Francisco.
Scott, thanks for joining.
Thanks, Don.
On the line with us now is Joe Palca, NPR science correspondent, out there at NPR West, out near sunny L.A., going to cover the Mars landing for us.
Joe, are you?
Yes, oh absolutely, Ira.
You know, we've done this a few times, haven't we?
I want to play a little bit of tape for you, Joe.
You may remember this.

I've got a little bit of tape from - if you're a longtime listeners, you may recall we were broadcasting live from the lawn of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory talking to Mars Pathfinder mission scientists waiting for word that the pathfinder had landed.
And unexpectedly, this happened.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED BROADCAST)
We have confirmed, we confirm that the spacecraft has now completed its final deployment, and we're transmitting our final semaphore on a low-gain antenna.
Oh, that's great.
We now expect to get a signal on the spacecraft at 2:09 Pacific Daylight Time with real digital data.
My good.
Unbelievable.
Stay tuned for more excitement from Mars Pathfinder.
(APPLAUSE)
Yeah, there's a little bit of excitement here in Pasadena, there really was.
Wow, it's exciting.
I was incredible.
And, you know, the guy who was speaking there, his name is Rob Manning, and he's now the chief engineer for this latest mission.
Is that right?
Tell us what this is - what's supposed to happen here.

Well, Sunday night Pacific Time, or Monday morning for you folks on the East Coast, at 10:30 or 1:30 a.m., Curiosity, which is way bigger than Pathfinder - I mean, Pathfinder, you know, they have a little model of it.
It looks like a toy.
It looks like it could have been made by Mattel or something.
In fact, you remember Mattel did make a toy of the Rover.
But that was tiny, and this thing is the size of a compact car, still six wheels, They have that in common.
This one is nuclear-powered, so no solar panels, so that makes it look different.
And it's huge, and it's going to come down with this wacky new landing system they've come up with called the Sky Crane.
Sky Crane.
Let me - let me bring in John Grunsfeld.
He's a NASA astronaut and associate administrator Science Mission's Directorate at NASA.
He joins us by phone.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Oh, thank you very much, it's always a pleasure, Ira.
Joe's been describing what you've been calling seven minutes of terror.
Why the movie-like thought about this?

Well, there's a couple of reasons why, but there's actually a video online, it's gone viral, called ""Seven Minutes of Terror,"" where folks from JPL who designed and built this system describe the entry, descent and landing.
Just by comparison, when we enter on the space shuttle, it's 40 minutes.
I wouldn't say it's 40 minutes of terror, but it's a relatively gentle event.
The Martian atmosphere is very thin.
It's like our atmosphere at 100,000 feet.
And so the entry, descent and landing phase happens much quicker.
In fact, it happens in just a little over seven minutes.
And so this basically Apollo-like capsule will hit the top of the atmosphere at 13,200 miles an hour and decelerate at up to 10 g's of acceleration, maybe 11 g's of acceleration.
And then there's a whole sequence of miracles that occur to put the Curiosity Rover safely on the surface, starting with this deceleration, which is guided.

It actually has the intelligence of Neil Armstrong encoded in its computers to try and guide it safely into the place where we can then deploy a supersonic parachute, which will, you know, with a huge pull open up and, you know, start grabbing the Martian atmosphere to try and slow it below the speed of sound, to get it slow enough and close enough to the surface, and it will still be screaming towards the surface at a couple of hundred miles an hour so that eight rockets can fire to decelerate it so that we can get into a hover position to slowly let down, as you said, on a sky crane, a bunch of wires - slowly let down the rover, deploy the wheels and gently set it on the surface before we cut all those wires, and the sky crane can fly aside and crash into the surface.
And that whole thing takes about seven minutes.
However, Mars is 248 million kilometers away, and so it takes about 14 minutes for the light to travel to Earth.
So at the point that we get the first signals that the Curiosity system, the Mars Science Laboratory, is doing its thing, it will have already landed.
And so the whole story, you know, also will take about seven minutes before we know the outcome.
She says the answer is to make sure there's a more unified command.
One recommendation is to establish a new interagency national operations center to coordinate the federal response and make sure everyone's on the same page.
But this isn't the last word on the issue.
A Senate investigation into the government's response is expected to release its findings and recommendations next month.
Pam Fessler, NPR News, Washington.
You can read the full White House review at NPR.org.
A Palestinian suicide bomber struck outside a shopping mall in the Israeli coastal city of Netanya today.
Five Israelis were killed and around 50 were wounded.
The radical group Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility.
Israel's defense minister promised a strong and quick response.
As NPR's Eric Westervelt reports, the bombing is another setback for peace following Israel's pullout from the Gaza Strip this summer.
ERIC WESTERVELT reporting:
The street was filled with glass and debris just outside the main entrance to the shopping mall in central Netanya.
Streaks of blood splashed high up on the cement wall.
Thirty-eight-year-old Naomi Mayer, an emergency rescue volunteer, was in her office a block away when the blast shook her desk.
Mayer says she grabbed her medical gear bag and was one of the first on the scene.
One injured woman was yelling, `My boyfriend!
My boyfriend!
Mayer says the woman then cried out for a female friend who lay nearby, bleeding.
(Through Translator) She kept on asking me, `Is she dead?
Is she dead?
and I didn't respond, but we took her into the ambulance.
Witnesses say shortly before the bombing, a civilian flagged down an Italian police officer passing by to warn that someone suspicious was walking toward the mall's entrance.
Policewoman Shoshi Attia told Israeli state TV that she shouted to security, `A terrorist, a terrorist!
Take his hand out of the bag!
She rushed toward the bomber, as did a mall security guard.
She said, `The bomber looked me directly in the eyes and pressed his thumb on the detonator.
Remarkably, the policewoman, who is pregnant, survived with only minor injuries.
The mall security guard is believed to be among the dead.
Police spokesman Micky Rosenfeld said the guards helped save lives.
Put it this way: If the individual would have arrived and made his way inside the mall itself, we would talk about a much higher number of individuals, Israelis, that would have been killed.
There is no such thing as stopping a hundred percent in suicide attacks.

The militant group Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility, saying the attack was, quote, ""to avenge crimes of the occupation."" This was the group's third suicide bomb attack in this coastal area of Israel, the second since Israel's withdrawal of settlers and soldiers from Gaza this summer.
Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas, who continues to struggle to exert his authority, condemned this latest attack and said he's issued orders to arrest those who planned it.

A senior Israeli military official who spoke to NPR on condition of anonymity charged today that Abbas has done nothing to act against armed militants even after, quote, ""we give them specific intelligence."" The official said of Islamic Jihad, `Now we have to go back and put a lot of pressure on these terrorists.
Tonight, Israel's defense minister, Shaul Mofaz, vowed a robust response.
Israeli Army Radio reports that Israel Defense Force officials have decided on more targeted killings, or assassinations, aimed at the leaders of Islamic Jihad.
The bombing could also complicate political maneuverings as both sides prepare for elections early next year.
Yosef Da'Aboul(ph), a businessman near the mall, says all he knows is that the attack has shaken him and his livelihood.
Mr.
YOSEF DA'ABOUL (Businessman): (Through Translator) I don't know about the elections, but we're a bus company, and for tourism, this is terrible.
Everything--our work stops.
We don't have any work now.
(Soundbite of traffic noise)
Less than two hours after the blast, with a kind of grim efficiency, city workers in Netanya began to scrub the streets clean.
A few feet away, a woman sat on a motorcycle and wept quietly.
She said she just found out her good friend was killed in the bombing.
Eric Westervelt, NPR News.
DAVID WELNA reporting:
I'm David Welna at the Capitol.
Judge Alito went from the White House to the Capitol Rotunda this morning, where he joined Senate Majority Leader Bill Frist to view the remains lying in honor there of civil rights icon Rosa Parks.
Coming out of the Rotunda, Alito ran into an old friend, Alabama Republican Senator Jeff Sessions, who offered him words of encouragement.
